title: Georgia House - Day 10 (2026-01-26)
summary:
Overview: The Georgia House session on January 26, 2026 featured a prayer and scripture reading by a retiring pastor, as well as a report from the Committee on Information and Odds. No substantive legislation was discussed.

Key Actions: None detected.

Bills Introduced (First Reading): None detected.

Notable Moments:
- Pastor Duane Huitt, who recently retired after 23 years as pastor of Ridge Road Baptist Church, gave the opening prayer and remarks. He encouraged the representatives to make their mark and do something meaningful for the people of Georgia.
- The representative from the 64th district, Kimberly New, introduced Pastor Huitt and spoke about his long career and dedication to serving the community.
- The Chair of the Committee on Information and Odds noted that this was the 10th day of the session, marking 25% completion of the legislative session.

Votes: None detected.

Attendance: A quorum was present, with all members voting to signify their attendance.

Adjournment: The session adjourned, with the next session date unspecified.

Very charismatic. They'll come up to you. And, sir, please, missua, missua, buy this, buy this, please, please. And obviously, as an American, I'll say no, thank you, no, thank you. Today I rise to talk about an important issue impacting way too many Georgians, and that is maternal mortality. I had the opportunity to thoroughly read through the Georgia Department of Health's Maternal Mortality Commission report, and something stood out to me starkly. Out of the top six causes of Georgia's abysmal maternal mortality rate, which include hemorrhage, mental health conditions, cardiomyopathy, cardiovascular and coronary conditions, embolism, and preeclampsia and ekelenopsia, most of them involved a chronic or underlying condition. And throughout the report, a common contributing factor to maternal death was chronic conditions prior to pregnancy. So while yes, the state of Georgia will give you access to Medicaid if you're already pregnant, and yes, I was glad to support legislation that extended Medicaid coverage to one year postpartum, I recognized that fully expanding Medicaid could have saved some of those lives. To clarify, if thousands of working Georgians that fall into the healthcare coverage gap had access to care prior to pregnancy, so they could manage chronic conditions for life-saving medicines and establish a relationship with a doctor for preventative health and education on risks associated with their condition, they may still be here. The department's report specifically states that a contributing factor to maternal mortality is, and I quote, patients had issues accessing medications and primary care to manage chronic conditions due to lack of insurance.
